Comment: This game illustrates two well known general principles : how bad it is to sacrifice too much development for material, and an attack against a king that cannot castle.

This game was played at intermediate/low level, so even if I tried to make this analysis solid and entertaining, an higher level player would certainly have stuff to correct in my notes. 
Anyhow, your comments are all welcomed. Happy reading !

After having analyzed the game, I think it was.
However as I played the move, it was a speculative play.

Here's some tactics ; black queen's best retreat is f5 as it holds the c2 square.
Even after an exchange black bishop will still be holding c2.
Eventually black will end up gaining quality and black knight can escape from a1 in late game due to "a" and "b" pawns advance.

Fritz says that the best finish should be : 14.Cc3 Fb4 15.Td1 Tf8 16.Dd5  Fd6 17.Fa3 Ff5  18.d3  -

(actually this is French comments : C = Knight, T = Rook , D = Queen , F = Bishop and R = King)
At this point black should have been more concerned with pieces development & king safety. Letting the queen on the "c" column exposes to a later Rook move in c1 pressing on c7.

At this point black's move was certainly played due to increasing pressure, and will obviously let the material balance in white's favor. But black could have figured out a defense the following way : 18...Qd6 19.Qh5 c6 20.Qg5  Kc8 21.Bxe5 h6 22.Qf4 which remains unclear but certainly not lost.

Only two bad options remain : 
- There's a quick mate afer 25...Re8 26.Nxe8 Bxe8 27.Qxd6  Kc8 [27...Bc7 28.Bg4 then Qxd7#] 29.Bg4  Bd7 30.Bxd7#
- Trying to pary the mate loses one more rook after 25...Rd8 26.Qxd6 Re7 27.Nxd7 Rxd7 (otherwise quick mate) 28.Qf8  then Qxa8.
